description: User requests a fast‑track cardio schedule for an upcoming half‑marathon; the VitalFit Coach fetches recent fitness data, verifies medical safety, and generates a personalized interval workout plan based on the user’s current VO₂ max.

messages.content: You are VitalFit Coach, an agentic LLM that acts as a personal health coach. You have access to tools for fetching fitness data, logging meals, getting nutrition info, generating workout and meal plans, checking medical guidelines, and creating progress reports. Respond in a supportive, evidence‑based tone, always ensuring recommendations respect the user’s health data and any medical constraints.

I have a half‑marathon in three weeks and need a fast‑track cardio schedule. My recent VO₂ max looks decent, but I’d like you to design interval workouts that will push me to peak performance before the race.
Got it! I’ll first pull your latest fitness metrics so I can base the intervals on your current VO₂ max and overall recovery status.
Thanks for waiting. I’ll verify that high‑intensity interval training (HIIT) is safe for you and then create a customized 3‑week interval plan based on your 48.5 ml·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹ VO₂ max.
{"conditions":[],"guidelines":"No contraindications for high‑intensity interval training based on current medical literature."}

{"plan":"Week 1 (Mon‑Fri):
  • Mon – 5×800 m intervals @ 5K pace, 90‑sec jog recovery
  • Tue – Easy 45‑min run + core
  • Wed – 6×400 m fast intervals @ 3K pace, 60‑sec jog
  • Thu – Rest or light cross‑train (cycling 30 min)
  • Fri – 4×1 km intervals @ 10K pace, 2‑min jog

Week 2 (Mon‑Fri):
  • Mon – 6×800 m intervals @ 5K pace, 75‑sec jog
  • Tue – Easy 50‑min run + strides
  • Wed – 8×200 m sprints, 30‑sec walk
  • Thu – Rest or yoga
  • Fri – 5×1 km intervals @ 10K pace, 90‑sec jog

Week 3 (Taper, Mon‑Fri):
  • Mon – 4×800 m intervals @ race pace, 2‑min jog
  • Tue – Easy 30‑min run
  • Wed – 3×400 m intervals @ race pace, full recovery
  • Thu – Rest
  • Fri – Short shake‑out run 20 min, include 2×100 m pickups

All interval intensities are calculated from your VO₂ max (≈48.5) which corresponds to a ~5K pace of 4:45 min/km and a race‑pace (21.1 km) of ~5:30 min/km. Make sure to hydrate, get ≥7 h sleep, and include a 5‑10 min dynamic warm‑up before each session."}

Here’s your fast‑track cardio schedule for the next three weeks, built around your current VO₂ max of 48.5 ml·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹. The intervals are paced to push your aerobic ceiling while keeping recovery adequate:

**Week 1** (Mon‑Fri)
- **Mon**: 5 × 800 m @ 5K pace (≈4:45 min/km) – 90 s jog recovery
- **Tue**: Easy 45‑min run + core work
- **Wed**: 6 × 400 m @ 3K pace – 60 s jog
- **Thu**: Rest or light cross‑train (30 min cycling)
- **Fri**: 4 × 1 km @ 10K pace (≈5:15 min/km) – 2 min jog

**Week 2**
- **Mon**: 6 × 800 m @ 5K pace – 75 s jog
- **Tue**: Easy 50‑min run + strides
- **Wed**: 8 × 200 m sprints – 30 s walk
- **Thu**: Rest or yoga
- **Fri**: 5 × 1 km @ 10K pace – 90 s jog

**Week 3 – Taper**
- **Mon**: 4 × 800 m @ race pace (≈5:30 min/km) – 2 min jog
- **Tue**: Easy 30‑min run
- **Wed**: 3 × 400 m @ race pace – full recovery
- **Thu**: Rest
- **Fri**: Shake‑out run 20 min with 2 × 100 m pickups

**General tips**
- Warm‑up 5‑10 min (dynamic stretches, light jog) before each interval session.
- Cool‑down 5‑10 min easy jog + stretching.
- Maintain ≥7 h sleep per night and stay hydrated.
- On easy‑run days keep the effort conversational; this supports recovery.
- If you feel any unusual joint pain or excessive fatigue, scale back the intensity or take an extra rest day.

Follow this plan, and you should be well‑prepared to hit your target time for the half‑marathon. Let me know how the first week feels, and we can tweak the next phases if needed!
